thread.title: Sailing team boss demands clear water
thread.title_full: Sailing team boss demands clear water

author: DAVID RICCIO
title: Sailing team boss demands clear water
text:
A picture from July this year showing pollution floating in Guanabara Bay, site of sailing events for the Rio 2016 Olympic Games.
DAVID RICCIO The Sunday Telegraph AUSTRALIAN sailing team boss Peter Conde has called on rival countries to join forces ahead of the 2016 Olympics and maintain pressure on the Rio government to ensure the sewage-blighted waterways are cleaned up in time for the games.
“It would be good if everyone in the sport kept the pressure onto the government to do what it really needs to do — to tidy the place up,’’ Conde said.
“We’re dealing with health and safety issues that are unusual for the sport to have to deal with.’’
Conde’s plea comes after Rio de Janeiro’s Olympic organising committee ruled out conducting viral tests of the human sewage-laden waterways where the 2016 Games’ sailing and aquatic events will be held, despite recommendations from the World Health Organisation.
Sailing during the Rio Olympics, to be staged in August next year, will be held at Guanabara Bay — where during previous test events sailors have navigated past large amounts of floating debris including swollen mattresses, timber doors, plastic bags and animal carcasses.
And despite an independent study showing dangerously high levels of viruses from human sewage at all Rio Olympic water venues for sailing, rowing, canoeing, triathlon and distance swimming, the World Health Organisation posted a statement on their website, ruling out more advanced viral testing.
“Testing using standard bacterial indicators is the basis of current global guidelines for monitoring bathing water in the context of public health. WHO does not currently recommend testing of viruses for routine monitoring because of a lack of standardised methods and difficulty interpreting results.”
Of the 10 sailing events, Australia are genuine medal chances in six, which gives reason as to why Conde is treating the health of his team as paramount.
Australian Sailing performance director for the past six years, Conde said Rio represented the most challenging Olympics to prepare for, on many levels.
“It’s massively challenging for us because we’re an equipment sport and we’re going to a continent that we don’t normally go too, so we’ve got massive logistical issues just to have boats there and to get there,’’ Conde said.
“And (the health of our athletes) is clearly a priority area that we didn’t have at the last games (in London) and its not just about water quality and about getting sick.
“It’s about detection for infection, detection for getting sick through food and safety.
“At the simplest level, it comes down to hygiene.
“We have sanitising wash, of which you would normally find in hospitals on our coach boats and everywhere when we walk into a building.
“We’re improving our immunity and resistance to disease before we get there with supplements and probiotics.
“We’ve got a set of protocols laminated and posted on our walls that say ‘if you get these symptoms than this is what you do.’
“Its about awareness and we’ll work hard on personal responsibility to be educated and act on these things.’’
